repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
This addresses a tricky bug discovered by @luukvbaal in the matrix chat. From my testing, this consistently fixes the issue. The solution is just to parse a language's self-injections after all other injections, which prevents what looks like some infinite recursion issues.

I'm not sure why it was the async parsing that caused this issue to present itself, I would think that it would have been a problem even with synchronous parsing :thinking: Maybe the issue is nonexistent when running only on a single pass (event loop iteration) somehow

NOTE: A separate issue was discussed where `:q` hangs, which is due to the fact that it will always wait until an async function completes and the callback is run. That is a separate issue, but shouldn't matter unless there are async functions that will run indefinitely.

comment_regular_data.body: Doesn't this also affect highlighting order of #31853? As now self is parsed last, leading to it having higher priority

I don't think this affects that, since the trees are iterated separately in `highlighter.lua`, in an order regardless of the order they were parsed. Also, all children are still parsed after their parent, even self children. The only difference is that children of the same language as the parent will be the last child to be parsed. My testing confirms that the behavior is the same before and after, as well (with and without that PR)
What is the issue? I couldn't find the description in the chat.

Basically, the parsing would run indefinitely (until hitting redrawtime) when there was a self injection along with a non-self injection. The failure was flaky, but reproducible with the big linux file with macro injections (injecting self) in conjunction with comment injections.

Since children were iterated with `pairs()`, sometimes the self-injection children were parsed before the others, which caused infinite recursion due to `_parse()` being broken up over multiple event loop iterations

(Note that refactoring `_parse()` to use a coroutine-based approach would avoid this problem, which could be done while still keeping the recurisive (non-coroutine) `step()` logic in `_async_parse()`

I think this happens for any tree with 2+ injections. Checking if the injection needs to be parsed may take more than 3ms on a big file (if there's a lot of trees, each has to be checked for intersecting the range). And the second injection is never parsed.
Interesting. Would this be helped by #32077? Also, does the behavior you described mean that this PR is not a true solution? (i.e. it did not work in those cases)

> Also, does the behavior you described mean that this PR is not a true solution? (i.e. it did not work in those cases)

Yes

> Interesting. Would this be helped by #32077?

It would make it much less likely to happen, but it would still be possible.

One solution would be to not decrease the timeout if no work was done for a language tree.

> One solution would be to not decrease the timeout if no work was done for a language tree.

This sounds like the best solution. A step should always do some work.
That makes sense. Although I cannot seem to reproduce the linked issue when using 2+ random injections, only if one is a self injection. Would you mind maybe giving the basic steps?

> That makes sense. Although I cannot seem to reproduce the linked issue when using 2+ random injections, only if one is a self injection. Would you mind maybe giving the basic steps?

Try decreasing the step timeout from 3ms to 1 ms. I didn't do that, but I am running this on a laptop.

I used nvim-treesitter, installed `printf` parser, and added `printf` calls to the big linux file. `printf` should be after "comment" in iteration order.

What happens if there are multiple trees within a languagetree, and multiple async parses on different ranges.

First async parse is executed, only tree 1 intersects the range. Tree 1 starts parsing, but doesn't finish. 
Second async parse is executed, now only tree 2 intersects the range and starts parsing. 

But it would use a parser that is in use by tree 1 (which looks like this is not allowed by tree-sitter)?
Ah, damn. Thanks a ton for looking into this. I think the coroutine solution is the way to go then- I'll rework this PR
Closing in favor of #32082, let me know if I missed anything in that one. From my testing it fixes the issue in both cases

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: fix(treesitter): prevent infinite recursion when parsing
